12th February, 1699.— A certain foreigner, dis- tinguished by an office which is held sacred among the nations, looking for comforts that are not eom- patible with the rigors of a northern climate, drank an immoderate quantity of wine, and in order to try and cool the heat of his body with the freezing air, drove round all the streets of the city in an open carriage, and did not return home until he had, by striking and banging against things, shattered the carriage so that it was no longer capable of bearing its burden and driver, He attributes it to his good luck that he was not caught by the Muscovite night- roverS, or massacred utterly, especially as tl1e main delight of the Muscovite populace is to rob and run riot against the Germans.⁵ We had a splendid proof of this ’to-day.
